title: Bug 50059: Resources not served when metadatacomplete=true in web.xml
description: Bug 50059: Resources are not served from /WEBINF/lib/{.jar}/METAINF/resources if metadatacomplete="true" is set in web.xml. Make a Servlet 3.0 web app (let's name it foo) with metadatacomplete="true" attribute set on the webapp element in the /WEBIBNF/web.xml.2.
OB: When metadatacomplete="true" is set in the web.xml, resources located in /WEBINF/lib/{.jar}/METAINF/resources are not served.
EB: The correct behavior is to serve the resources located in /WEBINF/lib/{.jar}/METAINF/resources even when metadatacomplete="true" is set in web.xml.
SR:
To reproduce the issue: 
1. Create a jar file (let's name it bar.jar) containing a single /METAINF/resources/index.html file.
2. Start the web app (foo) in Tomcat 7.0.2.
3. In a browser, navigate to http://localhost:8080/foo/index.html.
Expected result: A 200 response with the index.html file served.
Actual result: A 404 response is received.
However, if the web.xml is modified to metadatacomplete="false" and the application is restarted, accessing /foo/index.html will work as expected.
Note: This issue was also tested with Glassfish v3.0.1, and the resources are served as expected regardless of the value of the metadatacomplete attribute.
Based on a quick look at the Servlet 3.0 specification, it seems that the metadatacomplete attribute only regulates annotation and web fragment processing.
